TABLE OF CONTENTS

Map of the Blighted Residential District in Baltimore—Frontispiece
Letter of Transmittal, Commission on City Plan to Mayor
Members of Commission and Staff
Letter of Transmittal, Staff and Consultant to Commission
Acknowledgments
TABLE OF CONTENTS
INTRODUCTORY
Previous Report—its essential statements
Cure of blight must both rehabilitate area and decently house present inhabitants
Subsidy: from whom, to whom, how much
Procedure in collecting and evaluating data
Recommendations seek social values but must be economically sound and consistent
SCOPE OF PRESENT REPORT
: Evaluates Situation as to Blight
Discusses pertinent general Background
Compares costs and benefits of various Remedial Procedures
DETERMINATION OF AREA NEEDING HELP
We seek not a definition of Blight but a practical process of determining its presence
SYMPTOMS OF BLIGHT i
As to the Neighborhood
As to the Buildings
As to the People
Trends
Ten Census Tract Maps Compiled
Dwelling Units old
Dwelling Units substandard
Dwelling Units of low value
Building Values decreasing
Dwelling Units rentals low
Population crowded on land
Population crowded in dwelling units
High rate of Sickness
High rate of Juvenile Delinquency
High rate of Welfare Cases
THE “BLIGHTED AREA”



-

b



¥







Evidenced by coincidence of many symptoms
Contains different kinds of Blight
Interlocks at boundaries with better areas
OTHER CITY-WIDE CONDITIONS BEARING ON RESIDENTIAL BLIGHT
Principal non-white Areas
Tenant-occupied Dwelling Units
Amount of residential Construction and Cost per Dwelling Unit
Persons per Dwelling Unit
Vacancies in Dwelling Units
Buildings needing Major Repairs
Principal vacant Residential Areas
Population Trends
Land Uses and Present Zoning Plans
Schools
Parks, Parkways and larger Playgrounds
Recreation
Traffic Flow
Master Plan of Rapid Transit
